description: From Late Latin incubus, from Latin incubō (“nightmare, one who lies down on the sleeper”), from incubāre (“to lie upon, to hatch”), from in- (“on”) + cubāre (“to lie down”).

entries.meaning: (mediaeval folklore) An evil spirit supposed to oppress people while asleep, especially to have sex with women as they sleep.
A feeling of oppression during sleep, sleep paralysis; night terrors, a nightmare.
(by extension) Any oppressive thing or person; a burden.
examples: Again he felt the impulse of flight: but his body was a dry dead incubus that refused to obey his volition.

entries.meaning: (entomology) One of various of parasitic insects, especially subfamily Aphidiinae.
